title: Aussie golfer’s ‘super extreme’ DUI arrest
text:
Australian golfer Steven Bowditch arrested for drink driving, released to play Phoenix Open 2nd round Evan Priest, AAP with staff writers, FOX SPORTS February 4, 2017 2:28pm 
AUSTRALIAN golfer Steven Bowditch has been arrested for “super extreme” drink driving in the United States. 
The 33-year-old was bonded out of Scottsdale City Jail in Arizona on Friday after being held in-custody on an Extreme DUI charge which means a blood alcohol reading in excess of 0.20, police say. 
They confirmed that because the charge is a misdemeanour, Bowditch was able to see a judge and be released on bail to make his second-round tee time at the US PGA Tour’s Phoenix Open. 
“Our legal limit is 0.08 blood alcohol and he being a 0.204 is what we classify as super extreme,” Sergeant Ben Hoster told AAP. media_camera The mug shot taken by Scottsdale police. 
Bowditch still made his 12.25pm (local) tee time and shot a second successive three-over 74 to miss the cut. 
According to USA Today , Bowditch was taken into custody just after 1am after a police officer found him asleep at the wheel at a set of traffic lights. There had been earlier reports of a white truck “swerving all over the road”. 
Bowditch’s ranking has fallen to outside 300th in the world but he’s won two USPGA Tour events (in 2014 and 2015) and has been ranked as high as 54th. He has previously spoken of a long battle with depression.
